title: Black Men More Likely to Die From Firearm Homicide
summary: A study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine on April 24, 2018, reveals that firearm homicides are significantly higher among black men compared to white men in the United States, with the disparity being particularly pronounced in certain rust belt states. The researchers, led by Corinne A. Riddell, Ph.D., from McGill University, used the CDC's Wide-ranging Online Data for Epidemiologic Research database to compare rates of firearm and non-firearm homicides and suicides among black and white non-Hispanic men from 2008 to 2016. The study found that black men experienced an additional 9 to 57 firearm homicides per 100,000 annually compared to white men, especially in Missouri, Michigan, Illinois, Indiana, and Pennsylvania. Conversely, white men had higher rates of firearm suicides, with variations across states, including the largest differences in southern and western states. The study highlights the need for policy interventions to address homicide and suicide rates and their racial disparities.

title: Gun Violence in Virginia
summary: The data reveals that Black/African American individuals account for over half of gun-related injury emergency department (ED) visits in Virginia, with 53% of cases. Additionally, hospitalizations due to gun-related non-fatal injuries show that 87% of patients are male, and Black/African American individuals represent 69% of unintentional gun injuries. Regarding gun-related deaths, Virginia experiences a rate of 12.1 per 100,000, slightly above the national rate of 12.0. In particular, homicides account for roughly one-third of gun-related deaths, with a high rate of gun-related homicides among Black males. The state's gun-related injury and death rates emphasize significant racial disparities, with Black individuals disproportionately affected by gun violence compared to other groups.

title: PolitiFact VA: Black Virginians are disproportionately killed in gun ...
summary: Levar Stoney, Richmond's Mayor, stated that Black Virginians are eight times more likely than white Virginians to die from gun homicide. This claim is based on data from Everytown for Gun Safety and the CDC, showing that between 2016 and 2020, the firearm homicide rate for Black Virginians was 8.4 times higher than for white Virginians. The exact figure was rounded down to eight times in Stoney's statement. The CDC data shows 14.3 out of every 100,000 Black Virginians were killed by gun homicides, compared to 1.7 per 100,000 white Virginians. The statement was confirmed as accurate and rated True by PolitiFact.

title: Gun homicide rate for Black males 21 times higher than White males
summary: Black Americans accounted for 62% of the 19,350 gun homicide deaths in 2020, with Black males aged 10 to 24 dying by gun homicide more than 21 times as often as their White counterparts. The gun homicide rate in the U.S. saw a significant increase in 2020, rising by almost 35%, marking the highest level in over 25 years. The report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) attributes the increase to various factors, including economic, social, and psychological stressors, as well as disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite record funding for police departments, homicide rates have continued to rise.

The overall rate for gun homicide deaths across America took a drastic jump from 2019 to 2020, rising by almost 35%, to the highest level in more than 25 years.

title: Gun suicide and homicide: statistics shaped by race
summary: The pattern of gun deaths in the U.S. is divided along racial lines, with most white people dying from suicide and most Black people dying from homicide. This division is more pronounced in urban areas with higher homicide rates, predominantly affecting Black communities, while rural areas, largely white, see higher suicide rates. In Virginia, Black people experience significantly higher gun homicide rates compared to white people, with 102 Black homicides versus 15 white homicides. Additionally, there are 37 suicides among Black people and 82 among white people. Furthermore, 35% of Virginia's adults have a gun in their home.
